newsitem.title: USA: U.S. Mid-West power prices ease on warmer forecast.
newsitem.headline: U.S. Mid-West power prices ease on warmer forecast.

text.p: Spot wholesale electricity prices in the U.S. Midwest eased again for weekend and Monday delivery with some moderation expected from cold temperatures, brokers and markters said.
Montana Power planned to resume output from its 320 megawatt Colstrip unit 2 on Saturday and shut its 700 megawatt Colstrip unit 4 for about 36 hours beginning at about 0300 EST Saturday.
Separately, Union Electric's 1,125 megawatt Callaway nuclear power plant in Fulton, Mo. was boosting power following a scheduled refueling outage.
In the Mid-Continent Area Power Pool (MAPP), peak non-firm power deals were said to be scarce with few buyers willing to meet offers near $31.00 per megawatt hour (MWh).
MAPP peak next-day power had been talked at $30.00-33.00 per MWh on Thursday.
Off-peak non-firm MAPP power prices were said to be steady in the $8.50-10.00 area, with few deals being done.
In the Mid-American Interpool Network (MAIN) peak, non-firm power for weekend delivery was pegged at $18.00-20.00 per MWh, with Monday assessed at $21.00-23.00.
Next-day MAIN prices had been talked at $27.00-31.00 on Thursday.
Peak, non-firm electricity prices in the East Central Area Reliability Coordination Agreement (ECAR) for weekend delivery were assessed at $16.00-19.00 with Monday said to be at $19.00-21.00 per MWh.
Next-day peak ECAR was assessed at $22.00-28.00 on Thursday.
Off-peak next-day ECAR power was said to be trading near $15.00-17.00 per MWh.
December peak ECAR was talked steady at $20.25-20.50, while January/February ECAR was assessed higher at $22.00-22.40 from $21.80-22.25 per MWh on Thursday.
Peak non-firm power prices in the Southwest Power Pool (SPP) for Friday were talked lower at $17.00-20.00 with Monday pegged at $19.50-21.70 per MWh.
Peak SPP prices had been assessed at $25.50-28.00 on Thursday.
Off-peak prices throughout SPP were reported to be steady in the $13.00-15.00 area, traders said.
December SPP was assessed steady at $22.10-22.25, while January/February SPP was assessed steady at $22.95-23.15 per MWh, the sources said.
